pathophysiology.mechanism: Bilateral RAAS activation → impaired pressure natriuresis → volume overload
contributors: Sodium and water retention from RAAS activation
Impaired renal escape from volume expansion

clinical_presentation.timing: Often nocturnal (recumbent redistribution) or with exertion

imaging.CTA: Bilateral renal artery stenosis or solitary kidney stenosis
imaging.echocardiogram: Preserved EF, may have diastolic dysfunction, LVH

differential_diagnosis: Flash pulmonary edema from other causes (cardiomyopathy, arrhythmia)

acute.oxygenation: Supplemental O2, BiPAP, intubation if needed

definitive.revascularization: Renal artery stenting of hemodynamically significant lesions

definition.@value: Sudden-onset pulmonary edema caused by bilateral renal artery stenosis or stenosis to a solitary kidney, resulting from impaired pressure natriuresis and volume overload, representing the strongest indication for renal revascularization.

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Recognize flash pulmonary edema as a distinct clinical syndrome
Understand the pathophysiology linking bilateral RAS to pulmonary edema
Identify flash pulmonary edema as the strongest indication for renal stenting
clinical_pearls: Flash pulmonary edema is the BEST indication for renal stenting - dramatic response
Key clue: preserved EF + recurrent pulmonary edema = think bilateral RAS
CORAL trial excluded these patients - don't apply CORAL results here
Episodes often nocturnal - recumbent fluid redistribution
Pickering described this syndrome - bilateral RAS + recurrent flash pulmonary edema
70-85% of patients have no further episodes after revascularization
